metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: HTML class Attribute
The HTML class attribute is used to specify a class for an HTML element.
content.html: The HTML class attribute is used to specify a class for an HTML element.

content.text: Multiple HTML elements can share the same class.
content.html: Multiple HTML elements can share the same class.

content.text: The class Attribute
The class attribute is often used to point to a class name in a style sheet. It can also be used by a JavaScript to access and manipulate elements with the specific class name.
content.html: The class attribute is often used to point to a class name in a style sheet. It can also be used by a JavaScript to access and manipulate elements with the specific class name.

content.text: In the following example we have three <div> elements with a class attribute with the value of "city". All of the three <div> elements will be styled equally according to the .city style definition in the head section:
content.html: In the following example we have three <div> elements with a class attribute with the value of "city". All of the three <div> elements will be styled equally according to the .city style definition in the head section:

content.code:
London

 

London is the capital of England.

Paris

 

Paris is the capital of France.

Tokyo

 

Tokyo is the capital of Japan.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<style>
.city {
  background-color: tomato;
  color: white;
  border: 2px solid black;
  margin: 20px;
  padding: 20px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="city">
  <h2>London</h2>
  <p>London is the capital of England.</p>
</div>

<div class="city">
  <h2>Paris</h2>
  <p>Paris is the capital of France.</p>
</div>

<div class="city">
  <h2>Tokyo</h2>
  <p>Tokyo is the capital of Japan.</p>
</div>

</body>
</html>

content.text: In the following example we have two <span> elements with a class attribute with the value of "note". Both <span> elements will be styled equally according to the .note style definition in the head section:
content.html: In the following example we have two <span> elements with a class attribute with the value of "note". Both <span> elements will be styled equally according to the .note style definition in the head section:

content.code:
My Important Heading

This is some important text.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<style>
.note {
  font-size: 120%;
  color: red;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<h1>My <span class="note">Important</span> Heading</h1>
<p>This is some <span class="note">important</span> text.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Tip: The class attribute can be used on any HTML element.
content.html: Tip: The class attribute can be used on any HTML element.

content.text: Note: The class name is case sensitive!
content.html: Note: The class name is case sensitive!

content.text: Tip: You can learn much more about CSS in our CSS Tutorial .
content.html: Tip: You can learn much more about CSS in our CSS Tutorial.

content.text: The Syntax For Class
To create a class; write a period (.) character, followed by a class name. Then, define the CSS properties within curly braces {}:
content.html: To create a class; write a period (.) character, followed by a class name. Then, define the CSS properties within curly braces {}:

content.code:
London

London is the capital of England.

Paris

Paris is the capital of France.

Tokyo

Tokyo is the capital of Japan.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<style>
.city {
  background-color: tomato;
  color: white;
  padding: 10px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<h2 class="city">London</h2>
<p>London is the capital of England.</p>

<h2 class="city">Paris</h2>
<p>Paris is the capital of France.</p>

<h2 class="city">Tokyo</h2>
<p>Tokyo is the capital of Japan.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Multiple Classes
HTML elements can belong to more than one class.
content.html: HTML elements can belong to more than one class.

content.text: To define multiple classes, separate the class names with a space, e.g. <div class="city main">. The element will be styled according to all the classes specified.
content.html: To define multiple classes, separate the class names with a space, e.g. <div class="city main">. The element will be styled according to all the classes specified.

content.text: In the following example, the first <h2> element belongs to both the city class and also to the main class, and will get the CSS styles from both of the classes:
content.html: In the following example, the first <h2> element belongs to both the city class and also to the main class, and will get the CSS styles from both of the classes:

content.code_html:
<h2 class="city main">London</h2>
<h2 class="city">Paris</h2>
<h2 class="city">Tokyo</h2>

content.text: Different Elements Can Share Same Class
Different HTML elements can point to the same class name.
content.html: Different HTML elements can point to the same class name.

content.text:
In the following example, both

and

point to the "city" class and will share the same style:
content.html: In the following example, both <h2> and <p> point to the "city" class and will share the same style:

content.code:
Paris

Paris is the capital of France
content.code_html:
<h2 class="city">Paris</h2>
<p class="city">Paris is the capital of France</p>

content.text: Use of the class Attribute in JavaScript
The class name can also be used by JavaScript to perform certain tasks for specific elements.
content.html: The class name can also be used by JavaScript to perform certain tasks for specific elements.

content.text: JavaScript can access elements with a specific class name with the getElementsByClassName() method:
content.html: JavaScript can access elements with a specific class name with the getElementsByClassName() method:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction() {  var x = document.getElementsByClassName("city");  for (var i = 0; i < x.length; 
  i++) {    x[i].style.display = "none";  }}

content.code:
<script>function myFunction() {  var x = document.getElementsByClassName("city");  for (var i = 0; i < x.length; 
i++) {    x[i].style.display = "none";  }}</script>

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction() {  var x = document.getElementsByClassName("city");  for (var i = 0; i < x.length; 
  i++) {    x[i].style.display = "none";  }}

content.code_html:
<script>
function myFunction() {
  var x = document.getElementsByClassName("city");
  for (var i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
    x[i].style.display = "none";
  }
}
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction() {  var x = document.getElementsByClassName("city");  for (var i = 0; i < x.length; 
  i++) {    x[i].style.display = "none";  }}

content.text: Don't worry if you don't understand the code in the example above.
content.html: Don't worry if you don't understand the code in the example above.

content.text: You will learn more about JavaScript in our HTML JavaScript chapter, or you can study our JavaScript Tutorial .
content.html: You will learn more about JavaScript in our HTML JavaScript chapter, or you can study our JavaScript Tutorial.
